(Following is just my own opinions)
I think a lot of it comes from our lesson back from 2014 Umbrella Revolution. We learned it the hard way. That's why we insist on the "Be Water" strategy, the "leaderless" strategy, and the "Don't condemn each other" mantra, etc.
To be honest, our dissatisfaction towards the gov has also deepened as time passes, and the Extradition Bill is the point where everything bursts open. With a clear cause (against the erosion of legal system), a more developed platform to discuss and organize, we have united a lot of Hong Kongers this time. The unity is really amazing to experience, events could be just planned hours ago but hundreds will show up.

The leaderless idea is also crucial as everyone is equal and can propose any ideas to platform for discussions. It also enables ordinary citizens to actively self-organize events, instead of passively waiting on other organizations.

But to be honest, it isnt that effective considering gov has not backed down and listen to our demands... but it does unite us and show our determination to the world.

replies.msg:
tl;dr = HK protesters have gone from "can't win" to "just might win". If they lose, Xi will probably go down with them.

Not that long ago, the general consensus was that the best-case result the protesters could achieve was to wreck the business value of HK for the CCP and then leave. An exodus. Most old-school historian/journalists still hold this line... a CCP red-line, no way that's going to happen, will never agree, yada yada...

But, the damage to the CCP has likely already exceeded the value of HK to the CCP. Businesses are leaving China, some forced out by the protesters and others quietly looking for an exit. World sentiment is turning against the CCP, positions are hardening, and "business as usual" is getting to be a hard-sell for politicians. I expect if the CCP had a way they could just erase HK, good and bad together, they would do it in a heartbeat. They only have bad to worse options... getting worse by the day. A HK exodus is still probable, but no longer a certainty. That, by itself, is amazing.

The damage to the CCP is probably not yet at a point of no return, but it's getting close. I'm seeing a few questions on how the platform itself (LIHKG) is run, so I feel like I should say a little about how it all works here real quick, from how the platform itself works to how communication works among members.

LIHKG basics:
* Topics start at the top, and fall unless someone interacts with it and posts a reply to show that it's worthwhile/ useful. There is also an option to reply to a topic without bumping it, which actually makes the topic seem less useful to the algorithm and makes it fall quicker. Some topics get 'pushed' up while some get 'pulled' down. The voting system doesn't really affect where the topic is, but it does let users know how well-received the topic is, kinda like on Facebook with likes.
* Folks with the 'P' mark are usually new users of the platform who cannot rate or bump topics. These users are also limited to posting one topic per day. This wasn't the case before LIHKG became the go-to place to discuss the protests, but measures had to be taken to keep blue-ribbons/ wumaos etc. from using new accounts to post misleading information. P-marked users who signed up after June will retain their status until further notice. (Personally I think the 'P' mark system works well enough, and users are usually able to identify bad content and warn others about it.)

It's important to remember most users here are just your average Joe who also happens to care about the protests, meaning they don't really have a way to do major stuff.

As to how the decision-making process works:
* Since most of the big events happen on the weekends, we have ample time to collect information, such as government responses and news reports. Users then discuss the topic until a consensus is reached, and start thinking up ways to leverage the info for events.
* Users post topics where people vote on what they should do next via the upvote/ downvote system. With the topic, they can make suggestions to folks with more influence like politicians, who actually organise and conduct the marches.
* Frontliners don't really use LIHKG on the field, but people do use the forum as a way to relay information, which reaches the frontliners one way or another.
* There really aren't any established rules, but we all agree to stick together and not point fingers. Culture, meanwhile, doesn't do much to affect decision-making, but more so the protest ads.

Simply put, the movement is very decentralised, and pretty much follows the model of a direct democracy.

I hope I've given you a better idea as to how stuff works, feel free to ask more
